Class EquationSolver

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--EquationSolver
class EquationSolver
extends java.lang.Object

Prints a combination of digits and +-*%/= to create an equation from digits.

How it works:

  1. Store the given equation.
  2. Put the '=' operator halfway between the digits.
  3. Calculate a hash mapping each possible value of the left-hand side of the equation to any equation giving that value.
  4. Calculate a list of all possible equations on the right-hand side.
  5. Loop through the equations in (4). Calculate the value each time. If a key in the hash from (3) is found, return the left-hand combination + = + the right-hand combination.
  6. Move the '=' sign somewhere else (close to the middle, for efficiency) If '=' has already been tried in every location, admit defeat.
  7. Start again at (3).

Rationale:

  • One side uses a hash and another does not. This is kind of strange, but not without reason! The hash only stores the equations which are useful, whereas the list stores ALL equations. The hash calculations have all been done in advance, whereas the list ones haven't. Since we check against the hash several times, this is faster. The right-hand side isn't converted to a hash because it's probable we won't even have to calculate half the values at all.
  • I used LinkedLists and hashes because I'm used to C and PHP ;).
  • I used Javadoc for the hell of it.

Method Detail

findEquation

public java.lang.String findEquation()
Puts =,+,-,*,/ in between digits to make a valid equation.

Returns:
Equation, or empty string if none could be found

equalPlacementOrder

private int[] equalPlacementOrder()
Returns an array of preferred locations of '=' character. For efficiency, we'll try to put the '=' as close to the middle as possible (to reduce permutations). For example, in "1234" we'll first try (12)=(34) (where the brackets mean we'll put in operations). Next, try (123)=(4) and then (1)=(234).

Returns:
An array wherein the first element is the preferred '=' sign placement, followed by the second-best, etc.

matchLhsRhs

private java.lang.String matchLhsRhs(java.lang.String lhs,
                                     java.lang.String rhs)
Returns an equation with (lhs combination) = (rhs combination).

Parameters:
lhs - Left-hand digits
rhs - Right-hand digits
Returns:
Equation with =,+,-,*,/ -- or empty string if impossible

listCombinations

private java.util.LinkedList listCombinations(java.lang.String digits)
Returns a list of all possible combinations of digits and operations.

For example, listNumbers(12) will return a list with:

  • 12
  • 1+2
  • 1-2
  • 1*2
  • 1/2
  • 1%2

...where each of the preceding bullets is a String

This is a recursive function.

Parameters:
digits - String of digits
Returns:
List of combinations

permute

private java.util.LinkedList permute(char firstDigit,
                                     java.util.LinkedList combinations)
Puts the given char in the beginning of the LinkedList with operators.

For example, given the char 2 and a LinkedList with Strings 34 and 3+4, returns a LinkedList with Strings (234, 2+34, ..., 2+3+4, 2*3+4, and so on)

Parameters:
firstDigit - The digit to prepend in various ways combinations The combinations to which we prepend the digit
Returns:
A new LinkedList like combinations

getValue

private int getValue(java.lang.String s)
Returns an int from a String combination of digits and operators.

Parameters:
s - Combination of digits and operators, for example 12+3
Returns:
Value of s: for example, 15

isFirstTermZero

private boolean isFirstTermZero(java.lang.String s)
Returns whether the first set of digits in the given String is zero.

For example, the following will return true: 00+3

This will return false: 01+3

Parameters:
s - String starting with digits
Returns:
Whether the first set of digits is all 0

hashCombinations

private java.util.Hashtable hashCombinations(java.util.LinkedList combinations)
From a given LinkedList of Strings, gives Hashtable of value -> combination.

Parameters:
combinations - List of Strings of digits and operations
Returns:
HashTable mapping int value to String combination
